content:
I've just removed the extra line breaks in the expected output of Test 4.
https://imgur.com/a/ORSL2It

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Entertaining puzzle! The many test cases did mean I had to think properly rather than taking shortcuts, which is a good thing.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea, haven't seen such a problem. It's ok for an easy puzzle!
Not sure I understand, why does Zac and Vanessa yield Vac (test 2) but Ben and Jennifer only Bennifer and not also Jen (test 1)
HAHA this is great!

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle, the statement is clear & well formatted.
Probably way more tests/validators than what you would really need but that's not an issue :D

Hi,

For Ben and Jennifer why isn't Jen a valid combination?
It also has 2 shared letters and it's not shorter than Ben, it seems to follow all the rules.

For Cliff and Claire Huxtable the output is:
Cliff plus Claire = Claiff Clire
both have one shared letter but I don't see any rules preventing the use Cliff & Claire, they would have 2 shared letters CLiff + clAIRE & CLaire + clIFF

Cases
* In some pairs of cases, the names in the test all consist of a single word only, but that's not the case in the validator. For example "Priscilla Presley" and "Barack Obama". 

"Presley" and "Obama" may fall into the category of "extra information just as FYI, in case you need it for your Tabloid story", but well, it's also a bit confusing. After all, "Presley" and "Obama" are normally considered as part of the names.

Following the principles of
‚Ä¢ easier cases appear first, more difficult cases later, and
‚Ä¢ each pair should have similar coverage,
I would suggest to rearrange the input strings so that
‚Ä¢ no FYI information is tested in the initial pair(s)
‚Ä¢ FYI information is tested in the subsequent pairs

Goal section
* Following the above comment, I would suggest to mention that if a name consists of more than one word, only the first word is considered.

(That raises another question: Can the name before {{and}} consist of more than one word?)

Output section
* Please format n as a [[variable]].

Constraints section
* Please move "In Couple-Names, only the first letter is capitalized" to Goal section, as it is an output requirement, not a constraint.

* Maybe add a constraint that each name in the INPUT always starts with an uppercase letter and does not contain any other uppercase letters?

(e.g. "Linda McCartney" is a possible name in the input, but "McCartney Linda" isn't... Or can such names be tested? Take care not to contradict "In Couple-Names, only the first letter is capitalized", though.)

Thanks.

NOTE to ANYBODY:  I know my couples are pretty specific to America. So if you‚Äôre in a different place and have some suggestions for other couples for me to add, please do comment them here and I‚Äôll do my best to add them.

OMG! I can't stop laughing. I have no idea what your puzzle is actually about and my eyes are so filled with laughing tears, I don't know if I can keep reading. My name is Tim and my wife's name is Jo. How do you propose we combine those?
If it would help, we have two dogs named Barkley and Lulu. I really want to be a part of this puzzle!

As always, fantastic feedback. 
I‚Äôll work on this later today

Thanks so much for the feedback:

Jen is not valid because a couple-name has to be some part of the left of one person and some part of the right of the other person.  I should probably clearly state that, huh ??

I guess I need to clearly state that a couple- name cannot be exactly one of the individual‚Äôs names.

Both points are well taken; I will revise the description later today

Thanks!!!  Your initial feedback was so valuable in terms of really clarifying the method/ ‚Äúrules‚Äù

Yes I might have gotten a bit obsessive re the tests ü§™

It was just so fun to see the possible Couple-names for so many couples:  some are sooo funny and/or memorable and/or odd!!

Hi Rafarafa --

Thanks for the feedback.

Ben plus Jennifer could be "Bennifer": That has 2-overlapping letters ("en" from Ben and "en" from ennifer).
So per rule "Only Max Overlapping" we will NOT include any other options where there are less than 2 overlapping letters.

For Ben plus Jennifer to equal Jen (and have 2 over-lapping lettters), you would have to take the first part of Jennifer (Jen) and smoosh it with the last part of Ben (en).  (The 2 over-lapping lettters are "en").
That is not acceptable since it violates the "Must contain at least one letter from each person, that isn't part of the overlapping-letter(s)." rule.  Ben's entire contribution would be just the overlapping letters ("en"). (Poor Ben)

Whereas Vanessa plus Zac = Vac because "a" is the only overlapping letter.  So Vanessa contributes "Va" ( which is more than just the overlapping letter) and Zac contributes "ac" which is more than just the overlapping letter).

If you can think of any rephrasing etc that I should add, please tell me.
Thank ya üòä
Thank you, MrWaldron !

Yikes --okay, thanks.  

Should I check the others??
I think the others are fine, so you don't have to check them :) Maybe you need a line break checker for future contributions :P
Weird. I found that Test 13, Validator 15 and Validator 16 had issues too. I've removed the extra line breaks in the input of those cases just now.

Ah, that's entirely on me, yet is a tricky combination of the rules. In my mind it was valid since I was only considering the "e" as overlapping, but failed to realize that it had to be discarded then for having shorter shared substring length.

At any rate, I ended up solving it after that, not without failing at test 23 lol, so I guess the test abundance was not in vain :P

edit: I'm sorry, I just saw that @cedricdd made the same question a couple weeks before. Note taken, read the comments before writing one.

Absolutely no apologies needed. Feedback is so valuable!!!
(Cedricdd‚Äôs question was a little different than yours; because at that point I had it phrased very differently)
Just curious, what tripped you up on test 23??

It's kinda difficult to explain without showing my code but the capitalize logic wasn't working (as in, there was none, lol) and this didn't pass:
BoyAbba and ABBAGirl

And then the Alex Alexa was also giving Alexa since my logic for removing the original names (related to the capitalize logic) was off :/
All the tests/validators are green whit these rules :D
I did a lot of re-wording.  Would you mind taking another look?

It's a lot more clear now, you did a good job.
The only remark I have would be about:
"A Couple-Name cannot be the same as either of the individual's name because that's just silly"
Unless I'm mistaken this is redundant with the second rule, I don't think it's possible to generate a couple-name that's the same if you follow the second rule.

Thanks. :)

I think (??) I disagree about your remark because when I take that check out of my code I get Cliff and Claire as options for "Cliff and Claire" as you pointed out, earlier.

But I have been staring at this for way too long now.  Fresh eyes tomorrow will take a look

To make Cliff, nothing is specific to Claire, cl is overlapping & 'iff' is from Cliff
To make Claire, nothing is specific to Cliff, cl is overlapping & 'aire' is from Claire
So they would be against rule 2 but I might be wrong on that one.

When the "Overlapping"-Letter is "L".... 
Cliff plus Claire becomes   C + L + AIRE  -- which is Claire
Claire plus Cliff becomes C + L + IFF -- which is Cliff

Oh you're right, I did not consider the case where you're only using the 'L'.
Well you can scrap my remark then, sorry about that üò¨

I really appreciate the feedback.  
This whole concept can make my brain hurt a little bit.
Creating this has been a bit of a stretch for me, honestly.
I added a bunch more cases.  Would you mind running it and making sure you get "all greens" still -- in case I missed something?

That's a lot of tests, really going all in :D
I just had to change my regex because some of the new stuff are using "And" instead of "and' for the inputs.

Yes, I can get a little "obsessive" :)

I didn't mean to capitalize any of the ands, (I'm a victim of "copy and paste") so I'll go back and fix.  Thanks for checking :)
Thanks! Please let me know if you've finished and I'll take another look :wink:

I have done a lot of re-wording based on your suggestions, and Cedric's comments, and adding a bit more humor.
Would you please have another look.

Looks good to me :)

Just one more minor point: Please mention "or {{NONE}}" in Output section.

Thanks again!
Done‚Ä¶ Thanks !!!

Wow, I'm glad to entertain :)

I can't do much with that, but I tried some possible longer versions of those names.

Tim plus Jo = NONE
Timothy plus Jo = Jothy
Tim plus Josie = Josim Tie
Timothy plus Josie = Josimothy Jothy Timosie
Tim plus Josephine = Josephim Tine
Timothy plus Josephine = Josephimothy Josephy Timosephine Timothine

Personally, I like Jothy !!
You have made my day!
Barkley plus Lulu = Barklu Barklulu Luley
My 13-year old brother and sister yorki-poos are already sleeping easier.
Check out the new addition to Validator 5.

Awe????? Famous? I'm not so sure. Still, you're the best!!! It's after 8pm in Denver and I and the yorki-poos are fading fast. Someday, I'd like to share with you what went on in the leading lady's life today (Jo). She actually is famous in a dance sort of way. Much more so than I will ever be. For now, just imagine Chicago Midway airport and Black History Month. They have a DJ playing music at the gates and my wife shows up. Little did they know, she is the choreographer of the dance they are all doing there in the terminal!!! I would've loved to have been there!
